Cell Biol. 1999; 147: 267-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar), and several components of a homologous system have been identified in bacteria (13.Bogsch E.G. Sargent F. Stanley N.R. Berks B.C. Robinson C. Palmer T. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 18003-18006Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar, 14.Sargent F. Bogsch E.G. Stanley N.R. Wexler M. Robinson C. Berks B.C. Palmer T. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3640-3650Crossref PubMed Scopus (439) Google Scholar, 15.Weiner J.H. Bilous P.T. Shaw G.M. Lubitz S.P. Frost L. Thomas G.H. Cole J.A. Turner R.J. Cell. 1998; 93: 93-101Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). However, neither the mechanism of Delta pH pathway transport nor the function of its components is known with any certainty. One limitation has been that intermediate steps of the process have not been identified.In this study, we have identified a bound intermediate on the pathway. Certain truncated Delta pH pathway precursors bound tightly to the thylakoid membrane in the absence of the ΔpH and were transported into the lumen when the ΔpH was restored. The characteristics of precursor binding and the subsequent chase of bound precursor suggest that the precursor is binding to a component of the transport machinery. Antibodies to Hcf106 reduced the extent of binding, whereas antibodies to Tha4 had no effect on binding. These results suggest that precursor binding represents the first committed step of the Delta pH pathway.DISCUSSIONBecause protein transport on the Delta pH pathway requires no stromal components, it has been assumed that recognition and initial interaction with the translocation machinery occur on the membrane. Previous attempts to trap a bound intermediate on the thylakoids were unsuccessful. Such attempts were largely confined to the most commonly studied substrate, iOE23, which displays very little if any stable binding to the thylakoids (Ref. 22.Brock I.W. Mills J.D. Robinson D. Robinson C. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1657-1662Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar; Fig. 3). By surveying a range of Delta pH pathway substrates, we identified several substrates, most of them recombinant, that bind strongly to thylakoids when the pH gradient is dissipated.Tight binding occurred between precursor and thylakoids in the absence of the pH gradient, in the absence of stroma, and in the absence of NTPs (Fig. 1). It occurred equally well at low temperature and at 25 °C. Thus, there is no apparent energy requirement for strong interaction with the membrane. This differs from precursor interaction with the chloroplast envelope machinery, in which low affinity binding occurs in the absence of energy (19.Kouranov A. Schnell D.J. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 139: 1677-1685Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar), and tight binding requires NTPs and involves insertion into the translocon (1.Keegstra K. Cline K. Plant Cell. 1999; 11: 557-570Crossref PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar). It is unlikely that binding of Delta pH pathway precursors involves insertion into the putative translocon because the rate of transport from the bound state was not significantly faster than transport of freshly added precursors. This would suggest that there is an additional slow step on the membrane before the protein begins to appear in the lumen.If bound precursor is to be considered a true intermediate of the targeting pathway, it should exhibit several characteristics. First, it should proceed into the lumen when favorable conditions are restored. tOE17, iOE17, DT23, and DT17 exhibited productive binding (Fig. 3). Secondly, binding should be specific. Although we have not examined the interactions with a range of membranes, we have assayed for the ability of tOE17 to bind to the envelope membrane of intact chloroplast and found that binding to be extremely low. 4X. Ma and K. Cline, unpublished observations. Competition experiments (Fig. 6) indicate that productive binding is to a specific site on the thylakoids, a site associated with the Delta pH pathway (Fig. 6).In our study, the precursors that bound most strongly are not the physiological intermediates that occur in chloroplasts. However, we do not think that the observed binding is nonphysiological. Rather, we believe that binding of tOE17, DT23, and DT17 represents a stronger variation of the physiological process for several reasons. First, these substrates are translocated strictly on the Delta pH pathway (Fig. 1; Ref. 16.Henry R. Carrigan M. McCaffery M. Ma X.Y. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 823-832Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). In fact, when DT23 was used as a competitor of thylakoid protein transport, it very effectively competed for substrates of the Delta pH pathway, but it had no effect on the transport of the Sec pathway substrate, iOE33.4 Second, substrates that productively bind are more rapidly and efficiently transported than substrates that exhibit low levels of binding (Fig.2).4 Finally, at least two authentic Delta pH pathway intermediates, iOE17 and iPftf, bind to thylakoids. The physiological intermediate iOE17 binds to thylakoids, is transported from the bound state (Fig. 3), and exhibits all of the characteristics of binding and chase that were shown for tOE17 (Figs. Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3, Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6). Also, in a recent study, we showed that integration of the membrane protein Pftf is mediated by the Delta pH pathway. 5E. J. Summer, H. Mori, A. M. Settles, and K. Cline, submitted for publication. When Pftf integration was inhibited by dissipating the ΔpH, the physiological intermediate iPftf specifically bound to thylakoids.5The precise meaning of anti-Hcf106 inhibition of tOE17 binding is not yet clear. The fact that other thylakoid-binding antibodies (6.Mori H. Summer L. Ma X. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 45-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) had no effect says that it is not antibody coating of the membrane surfaceper se that was inhibitory, but rather antibody binding to Hcf106 that was important. Although the lack of effect of anti-Tha4 antibodies does not rule out Tha4 involvement in precursor binding, the reproducible inhibition by anti-Hcf016 argues that the Hcf106 protein plays some role in the binding process. One possibility is that Hcf106 directly binds the precursor. It has been suggested, based on its membrane topology, that Hcf106 functions as a receptor (11.Settles A.M. Yonetani A. Baron A. Bush D.R. Cline K. Martienssen R. Science. 1997; 278: 1467-1470Crossref PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar). Hcf106 and the homologous Tha4 are anchored in the thylakoids by single amino-proximal transmembrane helices, exposing larger carboxyl-terminal domains to the stroma. Indeed, the ability of anti-Hcf106 to inhibit binding and transport of precursors is analogous to the effects of antibodies to the chloroplast import receptor Toc159 (formally Toc86) on precursor binding and import into the chloroplast (23.Hirsch S. Muckel E. Heemeyer F. von Heijne G. Soll J. Science. 1994; 266: 1989-1992Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). However, it remains to be determined whether Hcf106 makes direct contact with Delta pH pathway precursors, in particular with their signal peptides.Another possibility is that Hcf106 is a component of a translocation complex and that antibody binding to any member of the complex impairs the ability of the machinery to interact with precursors. In fact, recent studies in our laboratory suggest that Hcf106 plays some role in translocation other than or in addition to signal peptide recognition. Specifically, a form of Pftf that lacks its signal peptide still depends on Hcf106 for its integration.5 If this latter model is correct, it might explain the incomplete inhibition of binding by anti-Hcf106 compared with the complete inhibition of transport (Fig.7). Resolving the precise role of Hcf106 either as a receptor or in some other aspect of the targeting and translocation process can now be addressed as a result of studies reported here. In plants, the photochemical reactions leading to ATP and reducing power take place on the thylakoid membranes within the chloroplast. Thylakoids contain well over 100 polypeptides, most of which are nuclear-encoded and synthesized in the cytosol as precursor proteins with transient amino-terminal transit peptides (see Ref. 1.Keegstra K. Cline K. Plant Cell. 1999; 11: 557-570Crossref PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar for review). For a thylakoid lumen protein, its transit peptide consists of two parts: 1) a stroma-targeting domain, and 2) a lumen-targeting domain. The stroma-targeting domain governs import of the precursor across the chloroplast envelope and is cleaved by a processing protease in the stroma, resulting in an intermediate precursor. The exposed lumen-targeting domain directs thylakoid translocation and is cleaved by a lumen-facing processing protease. There appears to be one major pathway for protein import across the chloroplast envelope. However, there are two pathways for protein transport into the thylakoid lumen (1.Keegstra K. Cline K. Plant Cell. 1999; 11: 557-570Crossref PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar, 2.Settles A.M. Martienssen R. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 494-501Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 3.Dalbey R.E. Robinson C. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1999; 24: 17-22Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). One pathway is called the thylakoid Sec pathway because this pathway uses chloroplast homologues of bacterial SecA, SecY, and SecE proteins (4.Nakai M. Goto A. Nohara T. Sugita D. Endo T. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 31338-31341Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5.Yuan J. Henry R. McCaffery M. Cline K. Science. 1994; 266: 796-798Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 6.Mori H. Summer L. Ma X. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 45-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar, 7.Schuenemann D. Amin P. Hartmann E. Hoffman N.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12177-12182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). A second pathway is called the Delta pH pathway because, for this pathway, the ΔpH across the thylakoid membrane is the only energy requirement for protein transport. Each pathway is specific for a subset of precursor proteins. The Delta pH pathway was first recognized as a distinct transport pathway when it was found that certain precursors, specifically OE171 and OE23, uniquely require neither soluble protein factors nor NTPs for transport but only the trans-thylakoid ΔpH (8.Cline K. Ettinger W.F. Theg S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 2688-2696Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A requirement for specific translocation machinery was demonstrated by precursor competition studies (9.Cline K. Henry R. Li C.J. Yuan J.G. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 4105-4114Crossref PubMed Scopus (172) Google Scholar) and by the demonstration that protease treatment of thylakoids destroys their ability to transport Delta pH pathway substrates (10.Robinson D. Karnauchov I. Herrmann R.G. Klösgen R.B. Robinson C. Plant J. 1996; 10: 149-155Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Two thylakoid proteins, Hcf106 and Tha4, were recently identified as components involved in transport on the Delta pH pathway (6.Mori H. Summer L. Ma X. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 45-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar, 11.Settles A.M. Yonetani A. Baron A. Bush D.R. Cline K. Martienssen R. Science. 1997; 278: 1467-1470Crossref PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar, 12.Walker M.B. Roy L.M. Coleman E. Voelker R. Barkan A. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 147: 267-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar), and several components of a homologous system have been identified in bacteria (13.Bogsch E.G. Sargent F. Stanley N.R. Berks B.C. Robinson C. Palmer T. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 18003-18006Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar, 14.Sargent F. Bogsch E.G. Stanley N.R. Wexler M. Robinson C. Berks B.C. Palmer T. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3640-3650Crossref PubMed Scopus (439) Google Scholar, 15.Weiner J.H. Bilous P.T. Shaw G.M. Lubitz S.P. Frost L. Thomas G.H. Cole J.A. Turner R.J. Cell. 1998; 93: 93-101Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). However, neither the mechanism of Delta pH pathway transport nor the function of its components is known with any certainty. One limitation has been that intermediate steps of the process have not been identified. In this study, we have identified a bound intermediate on the pathway. Certain truncated Delta pH pathway precursors bound tightly to the thylakoid membrane in the absence of the ΔpH and were transported into the lumen when the ΔpH was restored. The characteristics of precursor binding and the subsequent chase of bound precursor suggest that the precursor is binding to a component of the transport machinery. Antibodies to Hcf106 reduced the extent of binding, whereas antibodies to Tha4 had no effect on binding. These results suggest that precursor binding represents the first committed step of the Delta pH pathway. DISCUSSIONBecause protein transport on the Delta pH pathway requires no stromal components, it has been assumed that recognition and initial interaction with the translocation machinery occur on the membrane. Previous attempts to trap a bound intermediate on the thylakoids were unsuccessful. Such attempts were largely confined to the most commonly studied substrate, iOE23, which displays very little if any stable binding to the thylakoids (Ref. 22.Brock I.W. Mills J.D. Robinson D. Robinson C. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1657-1662Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar; Fig. 3). By surveying a range of Delta pH pathway substrates, we identified several substrates, most of them recombinant, that bind strongly to thylakoids when the pH gradient is dissipated.Tight binding occurred between precursor and thylakoids in the absence of the pH gradient, in the absence of stroma, and in the absence of NTPs (Fig. 1). It occurred equally well at low temperature and at 25 °C. Thus, there is no apparent energy requirement for strong interaction with the membrane. This differs from precursor interaction with the chloroplast envelope machinery, in which low affinity binding occurs in the absence of energy (19.Kouranov A. Schnell D.J. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 139: 1677-1685Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar), and tight binding requires NTPs and involves insertion into the translocon (1.Keegstra K. Cline K. Plant Cell. 1999; 11: 557-570Crossref PubMed Scopus (318) Google Scholar). It is unlikely that binding of Delta pH pathway precursors involves insertion into the putative translocon because the rate of transport from the bound state was not significantly faster than transport of freshly added precursors. This would suggest that there is an additional slow step on the membrane before the protein begins to appear in the lumen.If bound precursor is to be considered a true intermediate of the targeting pathway, it should exhibit several characteristics. First, it should proceed into the lumen when favorable conditions are restored. tOE17, iOE17, DT23, and DT17 exhibited productive binding (Fig. 3). Secondly, binding should be specific. Although we have not examined the interactions with a range of membranes, we have assayed for the ability of tOE17 to bind to the envelope membrane of intact chloroplast and found that binding to be extremely low. 4X. Ma and K. Cline, unpublished observations. Competition experiments (Fig. 6) indicate that productive binding is to a specific site on the thylakoids, a site associated with the Delta pH pathway (Fig. 6).In our study, the precursors that bound most strongly are not the physiological intermediates that occur in chloroplasts. However, we do not think that the observed binding is nonphysiological. Rather, we believe that binding of tOE17, DT23, and DT17 represents a stronger variation of the physiological process for several reasons. First, these substrates are translocated strictly on the Delta pH pathway (Fig. 1; Ref. 16.Henry R. Carrigan M. McCaffery M. Ma X.Y. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 823-832Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). In fact, when DT23 was used as a competitor of thylakoid protein transport, it very effectively competed for substrates of the Delta pH pathway, but it had no effect on the transport of the Sec pathway substrate, iOE33.4 Second, substrates that productively bind are more rapidly and efficiently transported than substrates that exhibit low levels of binding (Fig.2).4 Finally, at least two authentic Delta pH pathway intermediates, iOE17 and iPftf, bind to thylakoids. The physiological intermediate iOE17 binds to thylakoids, is transported from the bound state (Fig. 3), and exhibits all of the characteristics of binding and chase that were shown for tOE17 (Figs. Figure 1, Figure 2, Figure 3, Figure 4, Figure 5, Figure 6). Also, in a recent study, we showed that integration of the membrane protein Pftf is mediated by the Delta pH pathway. 5E. J. Summer, H. Mori, A. M. Settles, and K. Cline, submitted for publication. When Pftf integration was inhibited by dissipating the ΔpH, the physiological intermediate iPftf specifically bound to thylakoids.5The precise meaning of anti-Hcf106 inhibition of tOE17 binding is not yet clear. The fact that other thylakoid-binding antibodies (6.Mori H. Summer L. Ma X. Cline K. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 45-56Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) had no effect says that it is not antibody coating of the membrane surfaceper se that was inhibitory, but rather antibody binding to Hcf106 that was important. Although the lack of effect of anti-Tha4 antibodies does not rule out Tha4 involvement in precursor binding, the reproducible inhibition by anti-Hcf016 argues that the Hcf106 protein plays some role in the binding process. One possibility is that Hcf106 directly binds the precursor. It has been suggested, based on its membrane topology, that Hcf106 functions as a receptor (11.Settles A.M. Yonetani A. Baron A. Bush D.R. Cline K. Martienssen R. Science. 1997; 278: 1467-1470Crossref PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar). Hcf106 and the homologous Tha4 are anchored in the thylakoids by single amino-proximal transmembrane helices, exposing larger carboxyl-terminal domains to the stroma. Indeed, the ability of anti-Hcf106 to inhibit binding and transport of precursors is analogous to the effects of antibodies to the chloroplast import receptor Toc159 (formally Toc86) on precursor binding and import into the chloroplast (23.Hirsch S. Muckel E. Heemeyer F. von Heijne G. Soll J. Science. 1994; 266: 1989-1992Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). However, it remains to be determined whether Hcf106 makes direct contact with Delta pH pathway precursors, in particular with their signal peptides.Another possibility is that Hcf106 is a component of a translocation complex and that antibody binding to any member of the complex impairs the ability of the machinery to interact with precursors. In fact, recent studies in our laboratory suggest that Hcf106 plays some role in translocation other than or in addition to signal peptide recognition. Specifically, a form of Pftf that lacks its signal peptide still depends on Hcf106 for its integration.5 If this latter model is correct, it might explain the incomplete inhibition of binding by anti-Hcf106 compared with the complete inhibition of transport (Fig.7). Resolving the precise role of Hcf106 either as a receptor or in some other aspect of the targeting and translocation process can now be addressed as a result of studies reported here. Successful segregation of circular chromosomes inEscherichia coli requires that dimeric replicons, produced by homologous recombination, are converted to monomers prior to cell division. The Xer site-specific recombination system uses two related tyrosine recombinases, XerC and XerD, to catalyze resolution of circular dimers at the chromosomal site, dif. A 33-base pair DNA fragment containing the 28-base pair minimal difsite is sufficient for the recombinases to mediate both inter- and intramolecular site-specific recombination in vivo. We show that Xer-mediated intermolecular recombination in vitrobetween nicked linear dif “suicide” substrates and supercoiled plasmid DNA containing dif is initiated by XerC. Furthermore, on the appropriate substrate, the nicked Holliday junction intermediate formed by XerC is converted to a linear product by a subsequent single XerD-mediated strand exchange. We also demonstrate that a XerC homologue from Pseudomonas aeruginosa stimulates strand cleavage by XerD on a nicked linear substrate and promotes initiation of strand exchange by XerD in an intermolecular reaction between linear and supercoiled DNA, thereby reversing the normal order of strand exchanges. We also demonstrate that a XerC homologue from Pseudomonas aeruginosa stimulates strand cleavage by XerD on a nicked linear substrate and promotes initiation of strand exchange by XerD in an intermolecular reaction between linear and supercoiled DNA, thereby reversing the normal order of strand exchanges. base pair Holliday junction Tris borate-EDTA nucleotide maltose-binding protein A prerequisite for bacterial vegetative growth is that replicated chromosomes are segregated to distinct cellular locations prior to septum formation and cytokinesis (1.Donachie W.D. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1993; 47: 199-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). Homologous recombination between replicating or newly replicated circular replicons may produce chromosome dimers that cannot be segregated to daughter cells during cell division. In Escherichia coli, the Xer site-specific recombination system ensures that dimeric chromosomes are converted to monomers prior to cell division (2.Blakely G. Colloms S. May G. Burke M. Sherratt D. New Biol. 1991; 3: 789-798PubMed Google Scholar, 3.Kuempel P.L. Henson J.M. Dircks L. Tecklenburg M. Lim D.F. New Biol. 1991; 3: 799-811PubMed Google Scholar). The Xer system consists of a 28-bp1 recombination core site, dif, and two related tyrosine recombinases, XerC and XerD, that share 37% amino acid identity (4.Blakely G. May G. McCulloch R. Arciszewska L.K. Burke M. Lovett S.T. Sherratt D.J. Cell. 1993; 75: 351-361Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar). Tyrosine family recombinases contain a conserved tyrosine nucleophile and five other residues that have been implicated in catalysis (5.Argos P. Landy A. Abremski K. Egan J.B. Haggard-Lundquist E. Hoess R.H. Kahn M.L. Kalionis B. Narayana S.V.L. Pierson L.S. Sternberg N. Leong J.M. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 433-440Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar, 6.Abremski K.E. Hoess R.H. Protein Eng. 1992; 5: 87-91Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar, 7.Esposito D. Scocca J.J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 3605-3614Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar, 8.Sherratt D.J. Wigley D.B. Cell. 1998; 93: 149-152Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). Crystal structures for four members of the family have been solved, including XerD (9.Hickman A.B. Waninger S. Scocca J.J. Dyda F. Cell. 1997; 89: 227-237Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar, 10.Kwon H.J. Tirumalai R. Landy A. Ellenberger T. Science. 1997; 276: 126-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 11.Subramanya H.S. Arciszewska L.K. Baker R.A. Bird L.E. Sherratt D.J. Wigley D.B. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 5178-5187Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 12.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Duyne G.D. Nature. 1997; 389: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar). The dif site is present in the terminus of replication and consists of two 11-bp half-sites related by dyad symmetry and separated by a 6-bp central region that delineates the positions of strand cleavage and exchange (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). XerC binds to the left half-site where it cleaves and exchanges the top strand, whereas XerD binds to the right half-site and cleaves the bottom strand; binding of both recombinases is highly cooperative (4.Blakely G. May G. McCulloch R. Arciszewska L.K. Burke M. Lovett S.T. Sherratt D.J. Cell. 1993; 75: 351-361Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (267) Google Scholar, 14.Blakely G. Sherratt D. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 762-773Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). XerC and XerD act incis, with each recombinase cleaving a strand of the DNA site to which it is bound (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 15.Arciszewska L.K. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 2112-2120Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). A 33-bp fragment containing the minimal 28-bp dif site is also sufficient to enable both inter- and intramolecular Xer-mediated site-specific recombination in vivo (2.Blakely G. Colloms S. May G. Burke M. Sherratt D. New Biol. 1991; 3: 789-798PubMed Google Scholar, 16.Tecklenburg M. Naumer A. Nagappan O. Kuempel P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 1352-1356Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 17.Leslie N.R. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 1561-1570Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Xer recombination at dif sites present in the chromosome or in plasmids, however, is dependent on cell division and requires the septum-specific protein, FtsK (18.Steiner W.W. Kuempel P.L. Mol. Microbiol. 1998; 27: 257-268Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar, 19.Steiner W.W. Liu G. Donachie W.D. Kuempel P. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 579-583Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 20.Recchia G.D. Aroya M. Wolf D. Blakely G. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 5724-5734Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). FtsK localizes to the invaginating septum during cell division in a FtsZ-dependent manner and appears to have a dual role in chromosome segregation and septal ring constriction (21.Liu G. Draper G.C. Donachie W.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1998; 29: 893-903Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). Xer site-specific recombination is also involved in the stability of naturally occurring plasmids, such as ColE1 and pSC101, by ensuring that plasmid multimers are converted to monomers (22.Summers D.K. Sherratt D.J. Cell. 1984; 36: 1097-1103Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 23.Cornet F. Mortier I. Patte J. Louarn J.M. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 3188-3195Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). These plasmid-borne recombination sites consist of a core site, to which XerC and XerD bind, and ∼180 bp of adjacent upstream accessory sequences to which additional accessory sequence proteins bind (24.Stirling C.J. Szatmari G. Stewart G. Smith M.C.M. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 4389-4395Crossref PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar, 25.Colloms S.D. Bath J. Sherratt D.J. Cell. 1997; 88: 855-864Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Recombination at the pSC101 psi site occurs by sequential strand exchanges by XerC and XerD, respectively, whereas on the ColE1cer site, only XerC-mediated Holliday junction (HJ) intermediate formation has been observed (26.Colloms S.D. McCulloch R. Grant K. Neilson L. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1172-1181Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Interwrapping of accessory DNA sequences around the accessory proteins leads to a nucleoprotein complex of specific topology that can only assemble on and recombine directly repeated sites present in the same DNA molecule, thereby ensuring that recombination is preferentially intramolecular. This synaptic complex may also dictate in part that XerC-mediated strand exchange occurs first (26.Colloms S.D. McCulloch R. Grant K. Neilson L. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1172-1181Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Site-specific recombination mediated by λ Int also proceeds by a pair of ordered strand exchanges that lead to the formation of an HJ intermediate and its subsequent resolution to recombinant product (reviewed in Ref. 27.Landy A. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1993; 3: 699-707Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). The controlling factors that dictate which strand exchange will occur first, during both integrative and excisive recombination, have been ascribed to asymmetry produced by accessory proteins bound at the distal arm sites in the intasome (28.Nunes-Düby S.E. Matsumoto L. Landy A. Cell. 1987; 50: 779-788Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar, 29.Kitts P.A. Nash H.A. J. Mol. Biol. 1988; 204: 95-107Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). A preferential order of strand exchanges can also occur on core recombination sites in the absence of accessory proteins. For example, action of Haemophilus influenzae XerC and E. coli XerD on supercoiled molecules containing two dif sites leads to sequential strand exchange by H. influenzae XerC and E. coliXerD (30.Neilson L. Blakely G. Sherratt D.J. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 915-926Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). In this report we describe an in vitro assay that has allowed us to determine that strand exchange by E. coli XerC and XerD at dif is also initiated by XerC and that, on the appropriate substrate, the nicked HJ intermediate formed by XerC is converted to linear product by a single XerD-mediated strand exchange. We also demonstrate that a XerC homologue from Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PaXerC) stimulates strand cleavage by XerD on a nicked linear substrate and promotes initiation of strand exchange by XerD during intermolecular recombination between linear and supercoiled DNA. Binding of recombinases to DNA fragments was performed in buffer containing 20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 50 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mg/ml poly(dI-dC) (0.95 to 8 kilobases; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), and ∼0.1 pmol of labeled DNA for 10 min at 37 °C, prior to electrophoresis through 6% polyacrylamide in 1× TBE buffer at 4 °C (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Wild-type XerC, XerD, and PaXerC were purified by metal ion affinity chromatography using nickel-nitrilotriacetic acid resin (Qiagen) followed by fast protein liquid chromatography on MonoS columns as described previously (26.Colloms S.D. McCulloch R. Grant K. Neilson L. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1172-1181Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Maltose-binding protein fusions were prepared as suggested by the protocol from New England Biolabs. Synthetic oligonucleotides containing dif were based on the following sequences (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar): top strand, 5′GGGGATCCTCTAGATTGGTGCGCATAATGTATATTATGTTAAATCAGTCGACCTGCAGGC and bottom strand, 5′GCCTGCAGGTCGACTGATTTAACATAATATACATTATGCGCACCAATCTAGAGGATCCCC. The dif core site is underlined, with the central region sequence given in bold type. Oligonucleotides were 5′-labeled using T4 polynucleotide kinase with [γ32P]ATP before annealing and purification by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Suicide substrates were constructed by annealing two oligonucleotides, corresponding to left and right halves (30 nt each) of core sites to an oligonucleotide corresponding to the appropriate complete top or bottom strand (60 nt). The resulting substrate contained a nick in either the top or bottom strand of the core site central region. XerC and XerD (final concentrations of ∼400 nm for each) were added to ∼0.1 pmol of labeled substrate in binding buffer (as above) and incubated at 37 °C for 1 h. Reactions were halved; one half was electrophoresed through 6% polyacrylamide under nondenaturing conditions in 1× TBE buffer, and the other half was treated with SDS and EDTA to give final concentrations of 0.1% and 1 mm, respectively. SDS-treated samples were separated by electrophoresis through 6% polyacrylamide + 0.1% SDS in 1× TBE buffer containing 0.1% SDS (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Standard reactions contained 200 ng of supercoiled pMIN33 (2.Blakely G. Colloms S. May G. Burke M. Sherratt D. New Biol. 1991; 3: 789-798PubMed Google Scholar), 2 pmol of radiolabeled suicide substrate, and recombinases at a concentration of ∼400 nm each in a volume of 40 μl. Reaction buffer contained 20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 50 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, and 20% glycerol. Reactions were incubated at 37 °C for 16 h before addition of SDS and proteinase K to final concentrations of 0.1% and 0.4 mg ml−1, respectively, followed by electrophoresis through 0.7% agarose in 1× TBE and 0.1% SDS. Gels were subsequently stained with ethidium bromide to visualize plasmid DNA and then dried and exposed to x-ray film. Protein-DNA covalent complexes were precipitated with SDS and KCl as described previously (31.Trask D.K. DiDonato J.A. Muller M.T. EMBO J. 1984; 3: 671-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). Efficient recombination in vivo between dif sites shows a requirement for the C terminus of the septum-located protein, FtsK (19.Steiner W.W. Liu G. Donachie W.D. Kuempel P. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 579-583Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 20.Recchia G.D. Aroya M. Wolf D. Blakely G. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 5724-5734Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). Probably as a consequence of this requirement, we have been unable to detect recombinant products resulting from both pairs of strand exchanges between direct repeats of dif when present in a supercoiled plasmid after reaction with E. coli Xer recombinasesin vitro (26.Colloms S.D. McCulloch R. Grant K. Neilson L. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 1172-1181Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). To study strand exchange at dif, we modified an in vitro assay developed for λ Int that allows detection of partial and complete recombinant products formed during reactions between linear, nicked dif suicide substrates and dif sites present in supercoiled plasmid DNA (28.Nunes-Düby S.E. Matsumoto L. Landy A. Cell. 1987; 50: 779-788Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar). For a given linear substrate with a nick in either the top or bottom strand there are several possible outcomes of cleavage and strand exchange with a plasmid-borne dif site. These outcomes depend on which DNA strand contains the nick and which strands are cleaved and exchanged first. Examples of reactions in which XerC initiates top strand exchange on substrates nicked on either top or bottom strands are shown in a schematic (Fig.1). Catalysis by XerC on a top strand nicked suicide substrate (dT3) synapsed with a dif core site in a plasmid (pMIN33) would lead to cleavages of both top strands and the loss of a trinucleotide from the suicide substrate. The presence of an appropriately positioned free 5′ OH in the cleaved plasmid site would allow a single, potentially reversible, non-reciprocal strand exchange from the plasmid to the suicide substrate. The loss of the trinucleotide would ensure that a XerC monomer remains covalently linked to the plasmid DNA, because no adjacent 5′ OH is available for in-line attack on the covalent complex. XerC-mediated exchange of the top strands from the bottom strand nicked suicide substrate (dB3) with the top strand of the plasmid-bornedif site (Fig. 1 B) would generate an HJ-containing molecule in which the bottom strand was nicked. This HJ would then be a substrate for a pair of XerD-mediated cleavages and a subsequent single strand exchange by XerD. The XerD-mediated resolution of the HJ intermediate would produce a linear, nicked product containing a covalently linked XerD monomer. Note that only a single strand exchange occurs because one cleavage will generate a 3-nucleotide product that should diffuse away. This product could, in principle, be converted back to the HJ intermediate by XerD. If XerD-mediated strand exchange had occurred first in any of these reactions, then substrate dB3 would generate a single, non-reciprocal strand exchange, whereas substrate dT3 would produce one pair of XerD-mediated strand exchanges followed by a single XerC-mediated exchange. Reactions containing XerC and XerD, a radiolabeled difsuicide substrate, and supercoiled pMIN33 were incubated at 37 °C for 16 h before treatment with SDS and proteinase K, followed by analysis using agarose gel electrophoresis. The products of a single strand exchange or one pair of strand exchanges are expected to migrate at a position similar to that of open circular plasmid (the presence of covalently bound protein or an HJ should not significantly influence mobility on these agarose gels). Products arising from strand exchange between a nicked substrate and a supercoiled plasmid should have lost their supercoiling because of the strand discontinuity. Products resulting from sequential top and bottom strand exchanges will be linear and migrate similarly to linear plasmid DNA. Mobilities of radiolabeled recombinant products were confirmed by comparison to plasmid DNA stained with ethidium bromide and radiolabeled size markers (Fig. 2 C). Electrophoretic analysis of products from reaction of XerC and XerD with a top strand nicked suicide substrate (dT3; Fig. 2 A) and pMIN33 gave rise to a single product band that migrated in a position similar to open circular plasmid (Fig. 2 B,lane 2), consistent with it having arisen from either a single strand exchange mediated by XerC or one pair of strand exchanges mediated by XerD. This product represented conversion of 12% of the suicide substrate to recombinant product. The relative inefficiency of this reaction is probably related to the in vivo requirement for FtsK bound at the invaginating septum during division, a process that cannot be reconstituted at this time. Because we cannot differentiate between strand exchanges mediated by each recombinase in this reaction, XerD was replaced with XerDR148K, which is defective in bottom strand cleavage on nicked linear substrates as a consequence of substitution of a catalytic arginine, thus allowing us to determine the amount of strand exchange mediated by XerC. A single product migrating as open circular plasmid was detected in the reaction containing XerC and XerDR148K, the amount of which was equivalent to that produced in the presence of wild-type XerD (Fig. 2 B, lane 3). Reactions containing catalytically inactive XerCY275F and wild-type XerD gave no detectable products (data not shown). We conclude that XerC catalyzes a single strand exchange between the plasmid and dT3 to form the covalent complex described in the schematic (Fig.1 A). This conclusion is supported by our ability to affinity purify reaction products containing maltose-binding protein fusions of XerC (data not shown) and to precipitate the radiolabeled reaction products with SDS and KCl (Fig. 2 D; Ref. 31.Trask D.K. DiDonato J.A. Muller M.T. EMBO J. 1984; 3: 671-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). Precipitation of reactions containing either XerC and XerD or XerC and XerDR148K with substrate dT3 gave two products, one representing the suicide substrate covalently linked to XerC and the other representing the recombinant product (Fig. 2 D, lanes 2 and 3). Precipitation of reactions containing XerC and XerD with dB3 also gave rise to the expected covalent complexes of the suicide substrate with XerD and the recombinant product (Fig. 2 D, lane 5). Note that the smear running above the recombinant product inlane 5 is of unknown origin. The reaction of XerC and XerDR148K with dB3 gave no products that could be precipitated with SDS and KCl, demonstrating that the HJ-containing molecule observed from the recombination reaction did not contain a covalently linked recombinase (Fig. 2 D, lane 6). To confirm that XerC initiates catalysis in this intermolecular assay, reactions of XerC and XerD with a bottom strand nicked suicide substrate (dB3; Fig. 2 A) and pMIN33 were analyzed. Two products were detected from this reaction (Fig. 2 B,lane 5). The major product migrated at a position similar to linear plasmid DNA, consistent with it having arisen from a pair of XerC-mediated strand exchanges followed by a single strand exchange catalyzed by XerD. The minor product migrated at a position similar to open circular DNA and could thus have arisen from either a pair of XerC-mediated strand exchanges or a single strand exchange by XerD. Reaction of XerC and XerDR148K with dB3 and pMIN33 led to normal levels of the circular product but abolished the linear product (Fig.2 B, lane 6), consistent with XerC initiating catalysis to generate an HJ-containing circle that is a substrate for a single XerD-mediated strand exchange. Incubation of XerC or XerD alone with these DNA substrates did not produce any evidence of strand exchange under these reaction conditions (data not shown). To test whether intermolecular recombination could occur between radiolabeled, un-nicked linear dif DNA and supercoiled pMIN33, we performed reactions using XerC and XerD or XerC and XerDR148K. Both reactions generated single bands that correspond to circular products arising from one pair of XerC-mediated strand exchanges (Fig. 2 B, lanes 8 and 9). These presumptive HJ-containing intermediates will have lost their supercoiling as a consequence of branch migration of the HJ to one end of the molecule. Note that in this assay and in those using nicked linear substrates, the majority of the plasmid molecules in a reaction remain supercoiled after 16 h of incubation (Fig.2 C). To confirm that the products detected in these intermolecular assays resulted from strand exchange that rejoins the linear radiolabeled DNA strand to the plasmid-borne dif site and were therefore true products of Xer site-specific recombination, reactions were analyzed by denaturing gel electrophoresis. Analysis of reactions of XerC and XerD with radiolabeled dT3 substrate demonstrated the presence of a 65-nt fragment after digestion with HindIII. This is the predicted size of the fragment resulting from exchange of dif top strands by XerC (Fig. 3, lane 3). Similarly, HindIII digestion of a bottom strand nicked substrate radiolabeled on its top strand (dT60) produced a 65-nt fragment, consistent with sequential catalysis by XerC and XerD (Fig.3, lane 6). EcoRI digestion of reactions containing bottom strand-labeled dB3 generated a 74-nt fragment. This is the expected size of a fragment resulting from the exchange of a bottom strand by XerD (Fig. 3, lane 9). As expected, no XerD-mediated exchange product was detected for reactions containing a top strand nicked substrate in which the bottom strand was radiolabeled (dB60; Fig. 3, lane 12). These results are the first demonstration of an in vitrointermolecular recombination reaction mediated by E. coliXerC and XerD at dif, albeit with a non-physiological substrate. Products that arise from catalysis by both XerC and XerD are derived exclusively from sequential events in which an initial pair of strand exchanges by XerC are followed by XerD resolution of a nicked HJ intermediate. XerC is able to mediate intermolecular strand exchange in the absence of XerD catalytic activity and can use either nicked or un-nicked top strands as substrates for the reaction. Why does substrate dB3 allow both strand exchanges to occur, whereas the other two substrates only allow XerC-mediated top strand exchange? The products of XerC-catalyzed strand exchange between un-nicked T60 substrate and plasmid should be HJ-containing molecules, which, in principle, could be substrates for catalysis by XerD. The only difference between HJs derived from dB3, which undergo catalysis by XerD, and those from T60, which do not undergo XerD-mediated catalysis, is the presence of the nick on the dB3 bottom strand. We assume that the nick in the bottom strand of the HJ assists the molecule in adopting a conformation that allows XerD catalysis, whereas those without a nick are unable to adopt a conformation suitable for catalysis by XerD. Synthetic HJs derived from linear oligonucleotides are very poor substrates for XerD but are recombined efficiently by XerC, apparently because the top strands adopt a conformation favored for catalysis by XerC (32.Arciszewska L.K. Grainge I. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3731-3743Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 33.Azaro M.A. Landy A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3744-3755Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). The sss gene fromP. aeruginosa was originally isolated as a plasmid-encoded DNA fragment that complemented a mutation in a strain defective for pyoverdin production in the presence of Zn2+ (34.Höfte M. Dong Q. Kourambas S. Krishnapillai V. Sherratt D. Mergeay M. Mol. Microbiol. 1994; 14: 1011-1020Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar). Analysis of the predicted protein sequence demonstrated that it is a member of the tyrosine recombinase family with substantial homology to theE. coli proteins XerC (49% identity) and XerD (39% identity) (Fig. 4 A). Hereafter, we refer to this protein as PaXerC. To determine whether PaXerC is a functional homologue of the E. coli XerC (or XerD), we overexpressed and partially purified the protein. Radiolabeled DNA substrates containing the E. coli difsequence were used in gel retardation assays to ascertain whether PaXerC could interact cooperatively with either of the E. coli recombinases (Fig. 4 B). XerC and XerD are able to bind dif in the absence of their respective partner recombinase (Fig. 4 B, lanes 2 and 3), with binding of both recombinases to dif being highly cooperative (Fig. 4 B, lane 4; Ref. 14.Blakely G. Sherratt D. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 762-773Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Incubation of PaXerC alone with dif DNA produced no detectable protein-DNA complex (Fig. 4 B; lane 5), but a mixture of XerD and PaXerC produced a complex corresponding to occupation of both half-sites (Fig. 4 B, lane 6). This interaction is highly cooperative, because >90% of the substrate is bound at a concentration of PaXerC that does not show detectable binding of dif in the absence of XerD. The decreased mobility of the PaXerC-XerD dif complex, compared with the XerC-XerD dif complex, is suggestive of increased bending within the recombinase-DNA complex. PaXerC does not show cooperative interaction with XerC bound to dif (data not shown). We conclude that XerC and PaXerC are homologues that have common functional domains responsible for cooperative interactions with XerD. Recombinases XerC and XerD can cleave nicked, linear difsuicide substrates in vitro to generate recombinase-DNA covalent complexes that can be detected using denaturing gel electrophoresis. In standard reactions containing both recombinases, XerC efficiently cleaves the top strand of dif, converting 60–70% of the substrate to covalent complex after 1 h at 37 °C. Cleavage of dif bottom strands by XerD is considerably less efficient, converting approximately 1% of substrate to covalent complex (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 14.Blakely G. Sherratt D. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 762-773Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The preference for XerC catalysis may reflect the preferred order of strand exchange. Neither recombinase is able to cleave DNA efficiently in the absence of its partner, demonstrating that protein-protein interactions are important for determining which monomers are catalytically active in a synapse (13.Blakely G.W. Davidson A.O. Sherratt D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 265: 30-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). To confirm that PaXerC is a site-specific recombinase capable of cleaving DNA, dif suicide substrates containing nicks either in the top or bottom strands were used. To assist in determining which recombinase was responsible for cleaving either top or bottom strands, we employed mixtures of wild-type proteins and maltose-binding protein (MBP) fusions as differential size markers so that complexes of each protein with DNA could be distinguished during electrophoresis (14.Blakely G. Sherratt D. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 762-773Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). At the protein concentrations used, >95% of the DNA substrate was recombinase-bound (data not shown). Incubation of PaXerC and XerD-MBP with a top strand nicked substrate (dT3) produced a complex that migrated behind the substrate in a position equivalent to one monomer of wild-type PaXerC covalently linked to the DNA (Fig. 5 A,lane 2). The increased retardation of the covalent complex from a reaction containing PaXerC-MBP plus wild-type XerD with dT3 confirmed that PaXerC was responsible for cleaving top strands (Fig.5 A, lane 3). The analogous experiments using a bottom strand nicked substrate (dB3) demonstrated that XerD was competent for bottom strand cleavage in the presence of PaXerC. A dramatic feature of these reactions was that XerD cleavage ofdif was greatly stimulated in the presence of PaXerC and converted 40% of the substrate to covalent complex in 1 h, compared with 1% in the presence of XerC (Fig. 5 B). The amount of PaXerC covalent complex (3% of substrate) was also approximately 20-fold lower in comparison to reactions containing XerC (Fig. 5 B; Ref. 5.Argos P. Landy A. Abremski K. Egan J.B. Haggard-Lundquist E. Hoess R.H. Kahn M.L. Kalionis B. Narayana S.V.L. Pierson L.S. Sternberg N. Leong J.M. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 433-440Crossref PubMed Scopus (375) Google Scholar and data not shown). Therefore, the combination of PaXerC and XerD on dB3 leads to a reciprocal stimulation of strand cleavage by XerD and impairment of strand cleavage by its (Pa)XerC partner. This stimulation of partner,impairment of self-catalysis (SPIS) phenotype has also been observed to result from other mutations in XerC and XerD and is thought to result from altered XerC-XerD interactions (35.Hallet B. Arciszewska L.K. Sherratt D.J. Mol. Cell. 1999; 4: 949-959Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The SPIS phenotype of PaXerC is not observed on dT3, implying that DNA conformation and alterations in XerC-XerD interactions can influence which recombinase acts first. Previous work with λ Int, Flp, and Cre, as well as with XerCD, has implicated DNA conformation in the presence of recombinases as being a major influence in determining which particular recombinases are catalytically active (12.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Duyne G.D. Nature. 1997; 389: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar, 32.Arciszewska L.K. Grainge I. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3731-3743Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 33.Azaro M.A. Landy A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3744-3755Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Having shown that PaXerC stimulates XerD strand cleavage on a nicked linear substrate, we tested the consequences of mixing PaXerC with XerD in the intermolecular recombination assay. Addition of PaXerC-MBP and XerD to dT3 and pMIN33 gave rise to a single product that represented conversion of 1% of suicide substrate to recombinant product (Fig.6, lane 2). The product was confirmed as a single top strand exchange mediated by PaXerC when XerD was replaced with the cleavage-deficient XerDR148K (Fig. 6, lane 3). Reaction of dB3 with PaXerC-MBP and XerD gave only a single detectable product that had the mobility expected from a single strand exchange mediated by XerD on the bottom strand (Fig. 6, lane 5). This product is no longer detected when XerDR148K is used in the reaction, confirming that catalysis is by XerD (Fig. 6, lane 6). A similar level of product migrating at the same position was also detected when un-nicked linear DNA, T60, was reacted with pMIN33 in the presence of PaXerC-MBP and XerD. The electrophoretic mobility of this product corresponded to that expected for the reciprocal exchange of a pair of bottom strands mediated by XerD (Fig. 6, lane 8). The inability to precipitate this product with SDS and KCl indicates that it did not contain covalently linked recombinases (data not shown). The inefficiency of these reactions may reflect an inappropriate recombinase conformation induced by PaXerC that subsequently inhibits formation of a productive synapse. No products resulting from both PaXerC- and XerD-mediated cleavage were detected for any of these reactions even though both top and bottom strand exchanges could occur independently. Therefore, XerD-mediated bottom strand exchange occurs exclusively on dB3 and T60, whereas PaXerC-mediated top strand exchange occurs on dT3, a result that mirrors the cleavage reactions on the linear suicide substrates. We propose that in these intermolecular reactions, the positions of the nick in dT3 directs a protein-DNA conformation appropriate for PaXerC-mediated strand exchange, whereas the absence of a nick or a bottom strand nick directs a complex conformation suitable for catalysis by XerD. The appearance of XerD-mediated bottom strand exchange and the absence of exchange by PaXerC with substrates dB3 and T60 demonstrates that the order of strand exchange at dif has been reversed (cf., Fig. 2 B). This reversal correlates with the change in relative amounts of strand cleavage as determined using suicide substrates (Fig. 5 A). Our previous work has shown that XerC cleaves the top strand of linear dif DNA 60–70-fold more frequently than XerD cleaves the bottom strand; here we show that intermolecular recombination mediated by the E. coli recombinases also display a preference for XerC-mediated top strand exchange first. In the presence of PaXerC, however, the increase in bottom strand cleavages mediated by XerD now leads to a preference for bottom strand exchange during recombination. This demonstrates a correlation between the frequency of strand cleavage on nicked linear duplexes and the order of strand exchange in reactions that support sequential catalysis by XerC and XerD. These results provide experimental support for a model in which recombinase-recombinase interactions play a key role in determining which two of the four recombinase molecules in a recombining tetramer are active at any one time (12.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Duyne G.D. Nature. 1997; 389: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar). The crystal structures of Cre bound to HJ and synapsed duplex DNA (12.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Duyne G.D. Nature. 1997; 389: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar, 36.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Dyne G.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 7143-7148Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar) suggest a mechanism for the switch that reciprocally activates two of the four recombinase molecules while inactivating the other two. Furthermore, the structures provide a molecular basis for the proposal that a conformational change in a two-fold symmetrical HJ intermediate is required to convert a substrate appropriate for one specific pair of strand exchanges to a substrate suitable for the other pair of strand exchanges (37.Stark W.M. Sherratt D.J. Boocock M.R. Cell. 1989; 58: 779-790Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). Interactions between the C-terminal α-helix (the donor region) of one Cre monomer and an acceptor region close to the active site of an adjacent monomer link all four recombinase molecules into a cyclic network of protein bound to DNA. These interactions position two of the active site tyrosines adjacent to their scissile phosphates as a consequence of the two-fold symmetry of the recombinase-DNA complex. A small change in DNA conformation and in protein-protein interactions can convert this complex from one suitable for top strand exchange to one suitable for bottom strand exchange (12.Guo F. Gopaul D.N. Van Duyne G.D. Nature. 1997; 389: 40-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar). Preference for one of the two alternative conformations will therefore lead to a preferential order of strand exchange. Alteration in recombination site sequence can influence which strands are preferentially exchanged, apparently by determining the preferred DNA conformation (32.Arciszewska L.K. Grainge I. Sherratt D.J. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3731-3743Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 33.Azaro M.A. Landy A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3744-3755Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). The results here also suggest that Xer, like Cre, uses recombinase-recombinase interactions to coordinate catalysis. The use of two recombinases provides an additional level of control that may be involved in determining that XerC normally initiates catalysis on duplex DNA. The observation that the PaXerC-XerD combination not only stimulates catalysis by XerD but leads to impairment of PaXerC-mediated cleavage and strand exchange underlines the reciprocal switch from one activity state to another. The reversal of this switch with PaXerC in cleavage assays on linear nicked substrates demonstrates that coordination of catalysis is mediated at or before recombinase-mediated cleavage and suggests that it only requires interactions between one XerC and one XerD molecule, because there is no evidence for synapsis of two linear DNA molecules in these assays.

The Escherichia coli Fpg protein is a DNA glycosylase/AP lyase. It removes, in DNA, oxidized purine residues, including the highly mutagenic C8-oxo-guanine (8-oxoG). The catalytic mechanism is believed to involve the formation of a transient Schiff base intermediate formed between DNA containing an oxidized residue and the N-terminal proline of the Fpg protein. The importance and the role of this proline upon the various catalytic activities of the Fpg protein was examined by targeted mutagenesis, resulting in the construction of three mutant Fpg proteins: Pro-2 → Gly (FpgP2G), Pro-2 → Thr (FpgP2T), and Pro-2 → Glu (FpgP2E). The formamidopyrimidine DNA glycosylase activities of FpgP2G and FpgP2T were comparable and accounted for 10% of the wild-type activity. FpgP2G and FpgP2T had barely detectable 8-oxoG-DNA glycosylase activity and produced minute Schiff base complex with 8-oxoG/C DNA. FpgP2G and FpgP2T mutants did not cleave a DNA containing preformed AP site but readily produced Schiff base complex with this substrate. FpgP2E was completely inactive in all the assays. The binding constants of the different mutants when challenged with a duplex DNA containing a tetrahydrofuran residue were comparable. The mutant Fpg proteins barely or did not complement in vivo the spontaneous transitions G/C → T/A in E. coli BH990 (fpg mutY) cells. These results show the mandatory role of N-terminal proline in the 8-oxoG-DNA glycosylase activity of the Fpg protein in vitroand in vivo as well as in its AP lyase activity upon preformed AP site but less in the 2,6-diamino-4-hydroxy-5-N-methylformamidopyrimidine-DNA glycosylase activity.

Lysosomal β-d-galactosidase (β-gal), the enzyme deficient in the autosomal recessive disorders GM1 gangliosidosis and Morquio B, is synthesized as an 85-kDa precursor that is C-terminally processed into a 64–66-kDa mature form. The released ∼20-kDa proteolytic fragment was thought to be degraded. We now present evidence that it remains associated to the 64-kDa chain after partial proteolysis of the precursor. This polypeptide was found to copurify with β-gal and protective protein/cathepsin A from mouse liver and Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells and was immunoprecipitated from human fibroblasts but not from fibroblasts of a GM1 gangliosidosis and a galactosialidosis patient. Uptake of wild-type protective protein/cathepsin A by galactosialidosis fibroblasts resulted in a significant increase of mature and active β-gal and its C-terminal fragment. Expression in COS-1 cells of mutant cDNAs encoding either the N-terminal or the C-terminal domain of β-gal resulted in the synthesis of correctly sized polypeptides without catalytic activity. Only when co-expressed, the two subunits associate and become catalytically active. Our results suggest that the C terminus of β-gal is an essential domain of the catalytically active enzyme and provide evidence that lysosomal β-galactosidase is a two-subunit molecule. These data may give new significance to mutations in GM1 gangliosidosis patients found in the C-terminal part of the molecule. The released ∼20-kDa proteolytic fragment was thought to be degraded. We now present evidence that it remains associated to the 64-kDa chain after partial proteolysis of the precursor. Uptake of wild-type protective protein/cathepsin A by galactosialidosis fibroblasts resulted in a significant increase of mature and active β-gal and its C-terminal fragment. Expression in COS-1 cells of mutant cDNAs encoding either the N-terminal or the C-terminal domain of β-gal resulted in the synthesis of correctly sized polypeptides without catalytic activity. Only when co-expressed, the two subunits associate and become catalytically active. Our results suggest that the C terminus of β-gal is an essential domain of the catalytically active enzyme and provide evidence that lysosomal β-galactosidase is a two-subunit molecule. Sakuraba H. Oshima A. Scriver C. Beaudet A. Sly W. Valle D. The Metabolic and Molecular Bases of Inherited Disease. 2. McGraw Hill Inc., New York1995: 2785-2824Google Scholar). McGraw Hill Inc., New York1995: 2785-2824Google Scholar), while in galactosialidosis (GS) reduction of β-gal activity is secondary to a deficiency in the lysosomal carboxypeptidase protective protein/cathepsin A (PPCA) (2.d'Azzo A. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 7351-7367Crossref PubMed Scopus (2104) Google Scholar) using sense primer A (5′-GTGGATGGGATCCCCCAGGG-3′, corresponding to β-gal cDNA nucleotides 1389–1407, including theBamHI site at nucleotide 1397) and antisense primer B (5′-CCCCAAGCTTCATCATGAGTTGTGGGCCCAGGCTT-3′, corresponding to β-gal cDNA nucleotides 1679–1660, including an adapter sequence carrying a HindIII site and two stop codons). Using the full-length β-gal cDNA as template and primers A and B, a fragment corresponding to β-gal nucleotides 1389–1679 was amplified, carrying two translation termination signals and a HindIII site at its 3′-end. After BamHI/HindIII digestion, this fragment was linked to the BamHI fragment of normal β-gal cDNA ending at nucleotide 1397, to replace all of the β-gal cDNA located 3′ of the BamHI site at nucleotide 1397. At its 3′-end the polymerase chain reaction product was ligated to aHindIII site in the 3′-flanking vector sequence. To create a cDNA that codes for a β-gal deletion mutant in which the β-gal signal sequence (ending with Tyr28) is linked to Ser544 (coding for β-gal signal peptide in frame with the C-terminal domain of β-gal), nucleotide 134 of the β-gal cDNA was linked to nucleotide 1680. Primers were synthesized that span the fusion site: sense primer A (5′-CGCAATGCCACCTCCAACTACACGCTCCC-3′, corresponding to nucleotides 123–134 and 1680–1696) and antisense primer B (5′-CGTGTAGTTGGAGGTGGCATTGCGCAAGC-3′, corresponding to nucleotides 1691–1680 and 118–134). Using the β-gal cDNA (cloned into pBluescript) as template in separate polymerase chain reactions, primer B was combined with a sense primer that anneals at the 5′-flanking vector sequence, and primer A was combined with an antisense primer that anneals at the 3′-flanking vector sequence. Thus, in the first reaction (primer B), a fragment was generated, of which the terminal 24 nucleotides had the same sequence as the first 24 nucleotides of the product of the second reaction (primer A). These two fragments were annealed at their homologous termini and used as template for a third polymerase chain reaction using the primers that anneal at 3′- and 5′-flanking vector sequences. In this reaction, a fragment was amplified that corresponds to the β-gal cDNA lacking nucleotides 135–1679. During purification of the multienzyme complex containing β-gal, PPCA, and neuraminidase, a lysosomal-mitochondrial fraction was prepared from mouse liver and fractionated by gel filtration on a Sephadex G-200 column (Fig.1 A). All three enzyme activities co-eluted right after the void volume (peak I), while oligomeric forms of β-gal and PPCA eluted independently (i.e. PPCA dimers (∼104 kDa) and β-gal tetramers (∼256 kDa) and dimers (∼128 kDa) (Fig. 1 A)). Surprisingly, in samples displaying β-gal activity (peaks I and II), not only the 64-kDa mature form, but also two bands of apparent molecular mass of ∼24–22 kDa were clearly recognized by anti-β-gal precursor antibodies (Fig. 1 B). Furthermore, these low molecular weight proteins copurified with the multienzyme complex (peak I), after purification on a β-gal affinity column (p-aminophenyl β-d-thiogalactopyranoside-agarose) (Fig. 1 C). It is noteworthy that most of the β-gal eluted from thep-aminophenyl β-d-thiogalactopyranoside-agarose column was present in fraction 4, followed by a minor peak in fraction 5, which coincided with the pool of cathepsin A and neuraminidase activities (Fig.1 C). This elution pattern may depend on the fact that β-gal in complex with the other two enzymes (fraction 5) has a higher affinity for the substrate than its free form. Apparently, the association of the β-gal C-terminal fragment to the mature 64-kDa domain, although noncovalent, is stable enough to withstand harsh washes with 1 m NaCl solutions during the purification procedure. To verify the identity of the 22/24-kDa form (Fig. 1 B), N-terminal amino acid sequencing was performed. The obtained sequence coincided with that of mouse β-gal residues Ser546–Phe558 (Fig. 1 D,underlined), corresponding to Ser543–Phe555 in the human protein (Fig.1 D). Thus, the 22/24-kDa band represents a C-terminal fragment of the β-gal precursor, generated during its proteolytic processing in lysosomes. To prove that this mechanism of β-gal maturation into a two-subunit enzyme is conserved within other mammalian species, we purified the bovine multienzyme complex from cultured Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells (data not shown). Also in bovine cells, the C-terminal β-gal fragment co-purified with the multienzyme complex. The chemically determined N-terminal amino acid sequence was 69% identical to the mouse sequence (Fig. 1 D,underlined). Although the first amino acid of the bovine fragment did not coincide with that of its murine counterpart, both fragments start with a serine residue (Fig. 1 D), suggesting that the protease cleavage site could be between two serines. The high degree of similarity between the bovine, mouse, and human C-terminal β-gal sequences points to a fully conserved mechanism of proteolytic processing of the enzyme (Fig. 1 D). To verify if the 22/24-kDa fragment is also retained after normal processing of the human precursor, radiolabeled human fibroblasts were subjected to immunoprecipitation with anti-β-gal antibodies that recognize both precursor and mature forms of the protein (α-BV85 and α-n64, respectively). We also constructed a cDNA (B24) that separately encodes the C-terminal domain (Ser544–Val677; B24) and was tagged N-terminally with the β-gal signal sequence to ensure translocation of the polypeptide to the endoplasmic reticulum (see “Experimental Procedures”). This mutagenized cDNA was transfected in COS-1 cells to compare the size of its encoded fragment with that of the C-terminal fragment of β-gal in human fibroblasts. After SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, only the immunoprecipitated 85-kDa β-gal precursor and the 64-kDa mature form were readily detected in normal fibroblasts (Fig. 2,lane 1). However, deglycosylation withN-glycosidase F allowed the detection of an 18-kDa band (Fig. 2, lane 2) that comigrated with the overexpressed and deglycosylated B24 protein (Fig. 2, lane 6). This result suggests that both the C-terminal domain of human β-gal and the truncated B24 protein are glycosylated at two sites. Apparently, the presence of sugar chains on the C-terminal fragment alters its electrophoretic mobility and renders its detection difficult. Notably, all molecular mass forms of β-gal, including the 18-kDa band, were absent from β-gal mRNA-deficient GM1 gangliosidosis fibroblasts (Fig. 2, lanes 3 and 4). Thus, the C-terminal fragment is retained in the mature form of β-gal in human fibroblasts. The fact that the ∼60- and 18-kDa deglycosylated bands are not of equal intensity may be due to the 6-fold difference in number of leucine residues between these fragments. To further ascertain if the C-terminal peptide is indeed a component of mature and active β-gal, we cultured PPCA mRNA-negative GS fibroblasts in the presence of exogenous PPCA precursor.
